<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SPACE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/26/spacex-launch-first-crewed-nasa-mission-wednesday?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Someone Get Elon a Coffee
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="SpaceX launch" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xMTA3L3NwYWNleF9sYXVuY2guanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>SpaceX</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If you've been wondering what the opposite of quarantine looks like, tune into SpaceX’s livestream at 4:30pm ET today. Astronauts Robert Behnken and Douglas Hurley <a href="https://www.nasa.gov/specials/dm2/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">will be lifting off</a> from Cape Canaveral to a place far, far away on SpaceX’s Crew Dragon spacecraft.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">This launch will make big H History. It’s...</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The first crewed flight from U.S. soil into orbit since 2011 </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The first time a private company will send astronauts into orbit</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The Crew Dragon’s final test before getting the all-clear to run crewed NASA operations</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The itinerary: </strong>Within ~12 minutes of takeoff the Crew Dragon will be <a href="https://www.spacex.com/launches/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">cruising in orbit</a>. From there, it’ll journey 19 hours to the International Space Station, where Hurley and Behnken will share some interesting Earth stories with their new roomies, NASA’s Chris Cassidy and Russia’s Anatoly Ivanishin and Ivan Vagner. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">NASA hasn’t set an end date for the mission, but when the Crew Dragon does return, it’ll splash down off Florida’s coast and a SpaceX vessel will retrieve it. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Years in the making</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Since 2011, NASA’s been paying about $80 million/head to send astronauts into space on Russian rockets. In 2014, it started shopping for a cheaper date and handed SpaceX and Boeing $3.1 billion and $4.8 billion, respectively, to build those capabilities back home.  </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>SpaceX had a few problems on the way, but it’s faring better than Boeing. After a 2019 test flight failed, NASA </span><span><a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/emerging-tech/stories/2020/03/09/nasa-identifies-numerous-software-issues-boeings-starliner-flight-system?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">found</a></span><span> dozens of issues in Boeing’s preparedness and is deciding whether to proceed with another test.  </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Rewind some more: </strong>This public-private partnership goes back to the Obama administration, which <a href="https://www.planetary.org/blogs/jason-davis/2016/20160822-horizon-goal-part-3.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">retooled</a> NASA’s goals for space exploration and embraced commercial launch capabilities.  </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>NASA had always used commercial contractors to build rockets, but its engineers led design and build. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Now, NASA’s handed most of that off to private companies, which also get to keep their spacecraft. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>With growing competition for space dominance from China and Russia and a new military branch, the Space Force, public investment in the U.S. space industry is expected to increase.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SPACE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/26/meet-astronauts-robert-behnken-douglas-hurley?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Move Over Skywalker
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Nasa astronauts" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xMTA2L25hc2FfYXN0cm9uYXV0cy5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>SpaceX</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Curious about what it takes to pilot a NASA x SpaceX mission? Check out these resumes. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Bob Behnken, joint operations commander</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The <a href="https://www.nasa.gov/astronauts/biographies/robert-l-behnken/biography?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">St. Ann, MO, native</a> has a degree in physics and mechanical engineering from Washington University, a master’s and Ph.D. from Caltech, and started his high-flying career as a flight test engineer in the Air Force. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Behnken will handle the Crew Dragon’s rendezvous, docking, and undocking with the ISS and lead camp activities while aboard. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Doug Hurley, spacecraft commander</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The Apalachin, NY, native has a B.S. in civil engineering from Tulane, attended naval test pilot school in Maryland, and served as a Marine fighter pilot. Hurley will oversee the launch, landing, and recovery. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Fun fact:</strong> Both men were selected as astronauts in 2000 and have two spaceflights apiece under their belt. They’re long-time friends.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Double fun fact: </strong>Hurley and Behnken are <a href="https://www.cbsnews.com/news/spacex-nasa-astronauts-douglas-hurley-robert-behnken/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">married</a> to veteran astronauts Karen Nyberg and Megan McArthur, respectively. The four met as part of the NASA astronaut class of 2000. No pressure on their kids...</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Follow their mission at <a href="https://twitter.com/AstroBehnken?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Eauthor&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">@AstroBehnken</a> and <a href="https://twitter.com/astro_doug?lang=en&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">@Astro_Doug</a>.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SOCIAL MEDIA
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/26/widower-begs-dorsey-take-trump-tweets?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
When Trump Tweets, Dorsey Sweats
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Long walk, saltwater, the president of the United States, former congressman, baseless murder claims. Just another day in the life of Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, tech journalist Kara Swisher <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/26/opinion/trump-scarborough-twitter.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">revealed a letter</a> to Dorsey written by Timothy Klausutis. His request? Please take down President Trump’s tweets about my wife’s death. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The backstory: </strong>Trump re-upped his false claim that former congressman and current TV host Joe Scarborough was involved in the 2001 death of Klausutis’s wife, Lori, who was then one of Scarborough’s aides. Trump had made the claim in 2017, then began tweeting about it again last week and yesterday morning. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>“These conspiracy theorists, including most recently the President of the United States, continue to spread their bile and misinformation on your platform disparaging the memory of my wife and our marriage,” Klausutis </span><span><a href="https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/6927911-Twitter-letter.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">wrote</a></span><span>. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>Twitter gave a non-answer answer to Klausutis’s request, saying it'll have improved misinformation policies in place "shortly." But, for the first time ever, Twitter <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2020/5/26/21271207/twitter-donald-trump-fact-check-mail-in-voting-coronavirus-pandemic-california?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">did flag</a> two of Trump's other recent tweets about mail-in voting. It said they contain "potentially misleading information." </p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
MEDIA
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/26/not-hbo?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
It's Not HBO
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="HBO Max" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xMTA1L3N0cmVhbWluZy5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">It’s HBO Max, and the new streaming service <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2020/05/26/media/hbo-max-streaming-service-guide/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">officially launches</a> in the U.S. today. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The pitch: </strong>Take a shot of Sheldon and chase with Tony Soprano. At $14.99/month, it’s not cheap, but it has a cavernous content library drawing from 1) cable networks including TNT, TBS, and Cartoon Network 2) HBO (duh) and 3) Warner Bros.’s film and TV archive. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The drawbacks:</strong> A party with Sheldon and Tony would be...weird. By mixing HBO’s prestige content with laugh track sitcoms, parent WarnerMedia and grandparent AT&T are trying to make Max “all things to all people,” commented Rosenblatt Securities Senior Analyst Bernie McTernan. NYU Stern Prof. Scott Galloway used <a href="https://twitter.com/profgalloway/status/1198215889218347009?lang=en&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">stronger language</a>. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>And...HBO Max’s 10,000-hour arsenal is actually smaller than most of its rivals’. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line:</strong> The stakes are Battle at Hardhome-high. Ever since AT&T acquired Time Warner in 2018, it has poured all of its eggs in the HBO Max basket, and it will keep pouring...about $4 billion over the next three years.</p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
FOOD
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/26/apeel-sciences-raises-250-million-1-billion-valuation?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Apeel Keeps Things Fresh
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Almost two years ago, Morning Brew profiled a food waste startup called Apeel Sciences and asked readers whether you’d invest.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The answer is...yes, yes you should have. First of all, it has the word “sciences” in its name—no brainer. Second, the company has just joined the ranks of the unicorns, <a href="https://news.crunchbase.com/news/new-250m-round-helps-apeel-sciences-make-saving-food-more-appealing/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">raising $250 million</a> at a valuation of more than $1 billion. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Here’s some background:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Apeel has created a natural coating that extends fruit and veggie freshness, sometimes boosting shelf life up to 3x. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>It’s currently keeping avocados as hard as concrete at large supermarket chains (like Kroger) in the U.S. and Europe. Asparagus and cucumbers are </span><span><a href="https://www.axios.com/apeel-sciences-fundraise-76c09521-2750-468e-b8aa-331a9083cb6f.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">on tap</a></span><span>.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>Apeel claims it’s on course to save 20 million pieces of fruit from going bad at homes and retailers.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Now how about a demonstration?</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><img src="https://media.giphy.com/media/gi9CNMjd0Q5HcpcEXz/giphy.gif" class="img-responsive" width="640" style="width:100% !important;max-width: 640px; width: 100%;" alt="" data-reactroot=""></p>

style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0\"\u003e\nSPACE\n\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/26/spacex-launch-first-crewed-nasa-mission-wednesday?email={{profile.email}}\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nSomeone Get Elon a Coffee\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"SpaceX launch\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xMTA3L3NwYWNleF9sYXVuY2guanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eSpaceX\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIf you've been wondering what the opposite of quarantine looks like, tune into SpaceX’s livestream at 4:30pm ET today. Astronauts Robert Behnken and Douglas Hurley \u003ca href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/specials/dm2/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewill be lifting off\u003c/a\u003e from Cape Canaveral to a place far, far away on SpaceX’s Crew Dragon spacecraft.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThis launch will make big H History. It’s...\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe first crewed flight from U.S. soil into orbit since 2011 \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe first time a private company will send astronauts into orbit\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe Crew Dragon’s final test before getting the all-clear to run crewed NASA operations\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe itinerary: \u003c/strong\u003eWithin ~12 minutes of takeoff the Crew Dragon will be \u003ca href=\"https://www.spacex.com/launches/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecruising in orbit\u003c/a\u003e. From there, it’ll journey 19 hours to the International Space Station, where Hurley and Behnken will share some interesting Earth stories with their new roomies, NASA’s Chris Cassidy and Russia’s Anatoly Ivanishin and Ivan Vagner. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eNASA hasn’t set an end date for the mission, but when the Crew Dragon does return, it’ll splash down off Florida’s coast and a SpaceX vessel will retrieve it. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eYears in the making\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSince 2011, NASA’s been paying about $80 million/head to send astronauts into space on Russian rockets. In 2014, it started shopping for a cheaper date and handed SpaceX and Boeing $3.1 billion and $4.8 billion, respectively, to build those capabilities back home.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eSpaceX had a few problems on the way, but it’s faring better than Boeing. After a 2019 test flight failed, NASA \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/emerging-tech/stories/2020/03/09/nasa-identifies-numerous-software-issues-boeings-starliner-flight-system?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efound\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e dozens of issues in Boeing’s preparedness and is deciding whether to proceed with another test.  \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eRewind some more: \u003c/strong\u003eThis public-private partnership goes back to the Obama administration, which \u003ca href=\"https://www.planetary.org/blogs/jason-davis/2016/20160822-horizon-goal-part-3.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eretooled\u003c/a\u003e NASA’s goals for space exploration and embraced commercial launch capabilities.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eNASA had always used commercial contractors to build rockets, but its engineers led design and build. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eNow, NASA’s handed most of that off to private companies, which also get to keep their spacecraft. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eWith growing competition for space dominance from China and Russia and a new military branch, the Space Force, public investment in the U.S. space industry is expected to increase.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eCurious about what it takes to pilot a NASA x SpaceX mission? Check out these resumes. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eBob Behnken, joint operations commander\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe \u003ca href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/astronauts/biographies/robert-l-behnken/biography?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eSt. Ann, MO, native\u003c/a\u003e has a degree in physics and mechanical engineering from Washington University, a master’s and Ph.D. from Caltech, and started his high-flying career as a flight test engineer in the Air Force. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBehnken will handle the Crew Dragon’s rendezvous, docking, and undocking with the ISS and lead camp activities while aboard. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eDoug Hurley, spacecraft commander\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe Apalachin, NY, native has a B.S. in civil engineering from Tulane, attended naval test pilot school in Maryland, and served as a Marine fighter pilot. Hurley will oversee the launch, landing, and recovery. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eFun fact:\u003c/strong\u003e Both men were selected as astronauts in 2000 and have two spaceflights apiece under their belt. They’re long-time friends.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eDouble fun fact: \u003c/strong\u003eHurley and Behnken are \u003ca href=\"https://www.cbsnews.com/news/spacex-nasa-astronauts-douglas-hurley-robert-behnken/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emarried\u003c/a\u003e to veteran astronauts Karen Nyberg and Megan McArthur, respectively. The four met as part of the NASA astronaut class of 2000. No pressure on their kids...\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFollow their mission at \u003ca style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nWhen Trump Tweets, Dorsey Sweats\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eLong walk, saltwater, the president of the United States, former congressman, baseless murder claims. Just another day in the life of Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, tech journalist Kara Swisher \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/26/opinion/trump-scarborough-twitter.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003erevealed a letter\u003c/a\u003e to Dorsey written by Timothy Klausutis. His request? Please take down President Trump’s tweets about my wife’s death. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe backstory: \u003c/strong\u003eTrump re-upped his false claim that former congressman and current TV host Joe Scarborough was involved in the 2001 death of Klausutis’s wife, Lori, who was then one of Scarborough’s aides. Trump had made the claim in 2017, then began tweeting about it again last week and yesterday morning. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e“These conspiracy theorists, including most recently the President of the United States, continue to spread their bile and misinformation on your platform disparaging the memory of my wife and our marriage,” Klausutis \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/6927911-Twitter-letter.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewrote\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eTwitter gave a non-answer answer to Klausutis’s request, saying it'll have improved misinformation policies in place \"shortly.\" But, for the first time ever, Twitter \u003ca href=\"https://www.theverge.com/2020/5/26/21271207/twitter-donald-trump-fact-check-mail-in-voting-coronavirus-pandemic-california?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edid flag\u003c/a\u003e two of Trump's other recent tweets about mail-in voting. It said they contain \"potentially misleading information.\" \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\"
